text: The best way to discover what is so special about quadrilaterals in construction is to build several models and explore the relationship among the side lengths. Use polystrips to make and study several quadrilaterals.

Make a prediction

  • Will any four side lengths make a quadrilateral?
Student predictions will vary based on their past experiences.

Conduct the experiment

Equipment:

  • Polystrips and fasteners
  • OR digital polystrips (see Digital Note below directions)

Directions:

  • Choose any four numbers between 2 and 20 for side lengths. Use them as side lengths to build a quadrilateral.
  • If you can build a quadrilateral, try to build a different quadrilateral with the same side lengths.
  • Record the data in a table similar to the one below.
  • Make and study several other quadrilaterals.

Digital Note: To create your own digital polystrips, drag over the "Coordinate Grid" tool. Plot two points and double click one of them to create a line. Then, select the line and click on "segment label." Select "length" from the list to see how long the line you create is.

Analyze the data

  • What pattern do you see that explains why some sets of numbers make a quadrilateral and some do now? Does this agree with your prediction?

To construct a quadrilateral from four given side lengths, the sum of the three shortest side lengths must be greater than the longest side length.

When it is possible to make one quadrilateral from four side lengths, it is possible to make many different shapes from the same side lengths.
For example, a 3 - 5 - 3 - 5 would form a parallelogram.
If you reorder the sides to 3 - 3 - 5 - 5 you will have a kite.
Note that when you go from a 3 - 5 - 3 - 5 to a 3 - 3 - 5 - 5, you will have a different combination of sides that share a vertex. This forms a different shape.
• What combination of side lengths are needed to build squares? Rectangles? Parallelograms?

Special quadrilaterals can be made with the following combination of side lengths.

All four side lengths are equivalent: rhombus and square (if the angles are 90˚).

Three side lengths are equivalent: a special type of isosceles trapezoid.

Two side lengths are equivalent, or one pair of side lengths is equivalent: isosceles trapezoid (if the opposites sides are equal length).

Two pairs of side lengths are equivalent: parallelograms (if the opposites sides are equal length), rectangles (if the opposites sides are equal length and angles are 90˚), kites (if adjacent sides are equal length).

• Test your conjectures on the following side lengths. Which ones form a quadrilateral? Are any of these squares? Rectangles? Parallelograms? Explain why.
    • Shape 1: 6, 10, 15, 15
    • Shape 2: 3, 5, 10, 20
    • Shape 3: 8, 8, 10, 10
    • Shape 4: 12, 20, 6, 9

Shape 1

Side Lengths: 6, 10, 15, 15

Quadrilateral? - Yes

6 + 10 + 15 > 15

Special Quadrilateral:

Isosceles trapezoid (if opposites sides are same length)

Shape 3

Side Lengths: 8, 8, 10, 10

Quadrilateral? - Yes

8 + 8 + 10 > 10

Special Quadrilateral:

Parallelogram (if the opposites sides are equal length)

Rectangle (if the opposites sides are equal length and angles are 90˚)

Kite (if adjacent sides are equal length)

Shape 4

Side Lengths: 12, 20, 6, 9

Quadrilateral? - Yes

6 + 9 + 12 > 20

Special Quadrilateral:

Trapezoid (if the opposite sides are parallel)
None of the given side length combinations can be used to form a square, because a square requires all side lengths to be equal and the angles to be 90˚.
